Synchronizing Tasks

The synchronizing process updates the tasks in StarTeam by replacing information previously exported to StarTeam with the latest information about each task from Microsoft Project.

The exceptions are the Responsibility and Status fields. During the synchronization process, these fields are ignored to avoid overwriting changes made from StarTeam. Microsoft Project gives a task In Progress status when work is added to it and gives it Finished status when all work has been completed. However, StarTeam has a more elaborate set of status classifications, which provides project mangers with greater flexibility.

You should synchronize tasks whenever you level the Microsoft Project (.mpp) file, change task dependencies, or change data fields in an exported task. You can synchronize task information for a single task, a task hierarchy (the selected task and its children) or all the tasks linked to the current .mpp file.

Caution: Always import work records from StarTeam tasks into the .mpp file before selecting the Sync StarTeam Tasks command from the StarTeam menu in Microsoft Project.

If you do not have the access rights required to synchronize a StarTeam task at the task level, the task becomes unlinked from its corresponding Microsoft Project task, and the icon for the StarTeam task changes accordingly. The task is not deleted.

To update StarTeam task information from Microsoft Project:

  1. Select a task from Microsoft Project.

  2. Select StarTeam > Sync StarTeam Tasks from the Microsoft Project menu bar. The Synchronize Tasks dialog appears.

  3. Select one of the following options:

    • Selected task only (disabled if no task is selected).

    • Selected task and children (disabled if no task is selected or if the selected task has no children).

    • All exported tasks (default).

    Note: If no tasks are found in StarTeam that were created in Microsoft Project, a warning message appears.

  4. Click OK.

Inevitably, all changes to the .mpp file, whether due to resource restrictions or new requirements, result in certain tasks being moved or removed and new tasks being added. These changes make the task hierarchy displayed in StarTeam inconsistent with the one in Microsoft Project.

When you add new tasks to a section of the Microsoft Project task hierarchy that has already been exported to StarTeam, you must also export the new tasks to StarTeam. This action is required to use other StarTeam Microsoft Project Integration features with these tasks.

Although the Microsoft Project Integration permits a Microsoft Project task to be exported to only one StarTeam project, you can change the export relationship at any time. To do this, re-execute the Export Tasks command with a different project, view, or folder. Doing this replaces the original StarTeam project folder path stored in the Microsoft Project task with a new path. As part of this process, you can remove the StarTeam task and its children from the original project or keep it as a StarTeam task in the original project (although it will no longer be integrated with Microsoft Project).
